paper_metadata.title: Transparent radiative cooling cover window for flexible and foldable electronic displays
paper_metadata.citation: Lee, K. W., Yi, J., Kim, M. K., & Kim, D. R. (2024). Transparent radiative cooling cover window for flexible and foldable electronic displays. Nature Communications, 15(1), 4443.
paper_metadata.abstract: Transparent radiative cooling holds the promise to efficiently manage thermal conditions in various electronic devices without additional energy consumption. Here, we report transparent radiative cooling metamaterials with a thickness of 50 microns as a cover window of foldable and flexible displays by rational design and synthesis of embedding optically-modulating microstructures in clear polyimide.

research_information.objectives: The objective of this study is to develop transparent radiative cooling metamaterials as a cover window for foldable and flexible displays, which can efficiently manage thermal conditions without additional energy consumption.
research_information.methodology: The transparent radiative cooling metamaterials were synthesized by randomly distributing PMMA-SiO2 microstructures into a c-PI film. The optical, mechanical, and moisture-impermeable properties of the metamaterials were investigated, and the radiative cooling performance was experimentally confirmed under indoor and outdoor conditions.
research_information.key_findings: The synthesized metamaterials exhibit a high visible transmission of 85.5% in the 400-800 nm wavelengths with a controlled haze from 25% to 64%. The addition of PMMA-SiO2 microstructures to c-PI achieves 2.2 times higher elastic modulus and 1.6 times higher tensile strength than those of c-PI, while exhibiting elongation at break of >3.7%.
research_information.limitations: The increased thickness of the metamaterials from 50 μm to 200 μm further slightly increases the light emission from 94.6% to 95.9% in the atmospheric window, but the steady-state temperatures of the simulated displays instead increase from 54.6 °C to 56.7 °C due to the increased thermal resistance of heat conduction.
research_information.research_questions: Can transparent radiative cooling metamaterials be developed as a cover window for foldable and flexible displays? Can the metamaterials efficiently manage thermal conditions without additional energy consumption?
research_information.hypotheses: It is hypothesized that the transparent radiative cooling metamaterials can efficiently manage thermal conditions without additional energy consumption, and that the metamaterials can be used as a cover window for foldable and flexible displays.
research_information.assumptions: It is assumed that the metamaterials will have minimal sacrifice of visible transparency with the inclusion of microstructures, and that the metamaterials will have excellent light emission in the atmospheric window.
research_information.scope: The scope of this study is to develop transparent radiative cooling metamaterials as a cover window for foldable and flexible displays, and to investigate the optical, mechanical, and moisture-impermeable properties of the metamaterials.

technical_parameters.measurements: The measurements include UV-VIS-NIR light transmittance and reflectance at wavelengths of 300-2500 nm, IR light transmittance and reflectance in the wavelengths of 2.5-25 μm, and haze in visible light.
technical_parameters.specifications: The specifications include a thickness of 50 μm, a visible transmission of 85.5% in the 400-800 nm wavelengths, and a controlled haze from 25% to 64%.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The performance metrics include elastic modulus, tensile strength, and elongation at break.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The experimental conditions include indoor and outdoor environments, with a solar simulator used to simulate solar irradiance.
technical_parameters.materials: The materials used include c-PI, PMMA, and SiO2 aerogel microparticles.
technical_parameters.processes: The processes used include spin-coating, curing, and peeling off the substrate.
technical_parameters.equipment: The equipment used includes a UV-visible spectrometer, a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer, a universal testing machine, and a thermal imaging camera.
technical_parameters.quality_parameters: The quality parameters include visible transmission, haze, elastic modulus, tensile strength, and elongation at break.

paper_metadata.title: Treatment and recycling of spent lithium-based batteries: a review
paper_metadata.citation: Sameer Al-Asheh, Ahmad Aidan, Teeba Allawi, Fatma Hammoud, Humaid Al Ali, Maha Al Khamiri, Journal of Material Cycles and Waste Management (2024) 26:76–95
paper_metadata.abstract: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have a wide range of applications from electronic products to electric mobility and space exploration rovers. This results in an increase in the demand for LIBs, driven primarily by the growth in the number of electric vehicles (EVs). This growing demand will eventually lead to large amounts of waste LIBs dumped into landfills which can cause serious environmental problems.

research_information.objectives: The paper aims to review different recycling technologies including hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, direct recycling, and precise separation.
research_information.methodology: The paper reviews various recycling methods, including hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, direct recycling, and precise separation, and evaluates their advantages and disadvantages.
research_information.key_findings: The paper concludes that hydrometallurgy might be the most efficient method of recycling waste LIBs on an industrial scale.
research_information.limitations: The paper requires further experimental work to verify the success of hydrometallurgy in recycling waste LIBs.
research_information.research_questions: The paper investigates the treatment and recycling of spent lithium-based batteries.
research_information.hypotheses: The paper hypothesizes that recycling waste LIBs can lower the environmental impact and reduce the material and energy consumption.
research_information.assumptions: The paper assumes that the recycling process can be scaled up to an industrial level.
research_information.scope: The paper focuses on the recycling of spent lithium-based batteries, particularly those used in electric vehicles.

paper_metadata.title: Ultrahigh-throughput cross-flow filtration of solution-processed 2D materials enabled by porous ceramic membranes
paper_metadata.citation: S. Diaz-Arauzo et al., Mater. Horiz., 2024, 11, 5960-5971
paper_metadata.abstract: This work demonstrates a fully flow-based, exfoliation-to-ink system for electronic-grade 2D materials using an integrated cross-flow separation and concentration system, enabled by porous ceramic membranes.

research_information.objectives: To develop a fully flow-based, exfoliation-to-ink system for electronic-grade 2D materials using an integrated cross-flow separation and concentration system, enabled by porous ceramic membranes.
research_information.methodology: The system consists of two stages: cross-flow microfiltration (CF-MF) and cross-flow ultrafiltration (CF-UF), using ceramic membranes with micron-sized pores. The CF-MF stage separates the desired graphene nanosheets from the input LPE dispersion, and the CF-UF stage concentrates the graphene nanosheet dispersion in the retentate stream.
research_information.key_findings: The use of ceramic membranes enables 10-fold higher nanosheet concentrations and flow rates without compromising separation efficiency, resulting in significant improvements in environmental sustainability and cost.
research_information.limitations: The system may introduce challenges from membrane fouling, which can reduce efficiency and increase maintenance costs.
research_information.research_questions: How can ceramic membranes be used to improve the efficiency and sustainability of 2D material production?
research_information.hypotheses: The use of ceramic membranes will enable higher flow rates and concentrations, resulting in improved environmental sustainability and cost.
research_information.assumptions: The system will operate continuously without significant fouling or maintenance issues.
research_information.scope: The system is designed for the production of electronic-grade 2D materials, with a focus on graphene.

technical_parameters.specifications: The ceramic membranes have a pore size of 1000 nm and are rated upwards of 140 PSI.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The system achieves a mass throughput of 100 L/h and a feed concentration of 10 g/L.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The system operates at a temperature of 60°C and a pressure of 140 PSI.

technical_parameters.processes: The system consists of two stages: cross-flow microfiltration (CF-MF) and cross-flow ultrafiltration (CF-UF).

paper_metadata.title: Understanding the Effect of M(III) Choice in Heterodinuclear Polymerization Catalysts
paper_metadata.citation: Katharina H.S.Eisenhardt, Francesca Fiorentini, and Charlotte K.Williams. Inorg. Chem. 2024, 63, 23438−23449
paper_metadata.abstract: The ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of epoxides with CO2 or anhydrides is a promising strategy to produce sustainable polycarbonates and polyesters. Currently, most catalysts are reliant on scarce and expensive cobalt as the active center, while more abundant aluminum and iron catalysts often suffer from lower activities.

research_information.objectives: The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of M(III) choice on the performance of heterodinuclear polymerization catalysts for epoxide/CO2 and epoxide/anhydride ROCOP.
research_information.methodology: The study involves the synthesis and characterization of novel Al(III)K(I) and Fe(III)K(I) complexes, and their evaluation as catalysts for ROCOP reactions.
research_information.key_findings: The Al(III)K(I) catalyst exhibits outstanding activities in the cyclohexane oxide (CHO)/CO2 ROCOP, and at 1 bar CO2 pressure it is the fastest aluminum-based catalyst reported to date.
research_information.limitations: The study is limited to the evaluation of Al(III)K(I) and Fe(III)K(I) complexes as catalysts for ROCOP reactions, and does not explore the potential of other metal centers or ligand frameworks.
research_information.research_questions: What is the effect of M(III) choice on the performance of heterodinuclear polymerization catalysts for epoxide/CO2 and epoxide/anhydride ROCOP?
research_information.hypotheses: It is hypothesized that the choice of M(III) center will have a significant impact on the performance of the catalyst, with Al(III) and Fe(III) centers potentially offering improved activity and selectivity compared to Co(III) centers.
research_information.assumptions: The study assumes that the ligand framework and metal center are the primary factors influencing the performance of the catalyst, and that other factors such as solvent and temperature will have a minimal impact.
research_information.scope: The study is focused on the evaluation of Al(III)K(I) and Fe(III)K(I) complexes as catalysts for ROCOP reactions, and does not explore the potential of these complexes in other applications.

paper_metadata.title: Well-Defined Supported ZnOx Species: Synthesis, Structure, and Catalytic Performance in Nonoxidative Dehydrogenation of C3−C4 Alkanes
paper_metadata.abstract: The article discusses the synthesis, structure, and catalytic performance of well-defined supported ZnOx species in nonoxidative dehydrogenation of C3−C4 alkanes.

research_information.objectives: The main objective of the research is to develop a method for the precise preparation of catalysts with uniformly structured ZnOx species and to establish structure−activity−selectivity relationships.
research_information.methodology: The researchers used various methods, including in situ reaction of gas-phase metallic Zn atoms with OH groups on the surface of supports, one-pot hydrothermal synthesis, and impregnation/anchoring methods, to prepare supported ZnOx species.
research_information.key_findings: The researchers found that the intrinsic activity of ZnOx species depends on their speciation, and that the activity increases with an increasing number of Zn atoms in a ZnOx cluster from 1 to a few atoms (less than 10) and then decreases strongly for ZnOx nanoparticles.
research_information.limitations: The researchers noted that the loss of Zn is an irreversible process, and that further studies are needed to make Zn-based catalysts ready for commercial applications.
research_information.research_questions: The researchers investigated the effects of support and ZnOx speciation on catalyst activity, and the rate-determining step of the PDH reaction over different catalysts.
research_information.hypotheses: The researchers hypothesized that the structure of ZnOx species can influence coke formation as well as cracking reactions leading to CH4, C2H4, and C2H6.
research_information.assumptions: The researchers assumed that each Zn atom is active, and that the activity increases proportionally to the propane feed content.
research_information.scope: The research focused on the development of catalysts for nonoxidative dehydrogenation of C3−C4 alkanes, and the establishment of structure−activity−selectivity relationships.

paper_metadata.title: What Is the Current State of Sustainability in the Decorative Electroplating Industry? A Close Look at New Practices and Advances
paper_metadata.citation: Giurlani, W.; Pappaianni, G.; Biffoli, F.; Mariani, E.; Bonechi, M.; Giliberti, L.; Tufarelli, M.; Franzo, P.; Cianfanelli, E.; Innocenti, M.
paper_metadata.abstract: Electroplating is a key process in many industrial fields, but it is considered one of the most non-sustainable industries related to the manufacturing sector. This paper discusses the current state of sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry, highlighting new practices and advances.

research_information.objectives: The objective of this research is to discuss the current state of sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry and highlight new practices and advances.
research_information.methodology: The research methodology involves a review of existing literature and case studies on sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry.
research_information.key_findings: The key findings of this research include the importance of sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry, the need for new practices and advances, and the potential for improvement through the use of computational methods, deposition systems, and metal recovery techniques.
research_information.limitations: The limitations of this research include the focus on the decorative electroplating industry and the need for further research on other industries.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions addressed in this paper include: What is the current state of sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry? What new practices and advances are being implemented to improve sustainability?
research_information.hypotheses: The hypotheses of this research include: The decorative electroplating industry has a significant impact on the environment and human health. New practices and advances can improve sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions of this research include: The decorative electroplating industry is a significant contributor to environmental pollution and human health risks. New practices and advances can be implemented to improve sustainability in the decorative electroplating industry.
research_information.scope: The scope of this research includes the decorative electroplating industry and the potential for improvement through the use of computational methods, deposition systems, and metal recovery techniques.

technical_parameters.measurements: The measurements used in this research include the thickness of electrodeposited gold, the standard deviation of the thickness, and the percentage standard deviation.
technical_parameters.specifications: The specifications of the materials and methods used in this research are given in Supplementary S1.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The performance metrics used in this research include the average thickness, standard deviation, and percentage standard deviation of electrodeposited gold.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The experimental conditions used in this research include the use of a 500 L electroplating tank, a central cathodic bar, and a heating element.
technical_parameters.materials: The materials used in this research include gold, copper, and nickel.
technical_parameters.processes: The processes used in this research include electroplating, deposition, and metal recovery.

paper_metadata.title: X-ray transmission imaging of waste printed circuit boards for value estimation in recycling using machine learning
paper_metadata.citation: Firsching, M., Ottenweller, M., Leisner, J., & Rüger, S. (2024). X-ray transmission imaging of waste printed circuit boards for value estimation in recycling using machine learning. Waste Management & Research, 42(9), 759–766.
paper_metadata.abstract: The growing amount of electronic waste is a global challenge, posing a threat to the environment and containing valuable materials like gold and copper. This article introduces a method for value estimation of entire waste printed circuit boards (WPCBs) based on component detection using X-ray transmission imaging and machine learning.

research_information.objectives: The objective of this research is to develop a method for estimating the material value of WPCBs for recycling using X-ray transmission imaging and machine learning.
research_information.methodology: The methodology involves using a deep neural object detection network called YOLOv5 to detect valuable components on entire WPCBs from X-ray images, and then estimating the value of the WPCB based on the detected components.
research_information.key_findings: The key findings of this research include the successful detection of different component classes using the YOLOv5 model, and the estimation of the value of WPCBs based on the detected components.
research_information.limitations: The limitations of this research include the small training set used, and the fact that the method is not yet proven for medium- and low-grade WPCBs.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions addressed in this study include: Can X-ray transmission imaging be used to detect valuable components on WPCBs? Can machine learning be used to estimate the value of WPCBs based on the detected components?
research_information.hypotheses: The hypotheses of this research include: X-ray transmission imaging can be used to detect valuable components on WPCBs, and machine learning can be used to estimate the value of WPCBs based on the detected components.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions of this research include: The value of WPCBs can be estimated based on the detected components, and the YOLOv5 model can be used to detect valuable components on WPCBs.
research_information.scope: The scope of this research includes the development of a method for estimating the material value of WPCBs for recycling using X-ray transmission imaging and machine learning.

technical_parameters.measurements: The X-ray transmission images were performed using a Comet MXR-225HP/11 X-ray source operating at 100 kV and 15 mA, and a Hamamatsu C10800-09FCM-C dual energy line detector with a pixel pitch of 0.4 mm.
technical_parameters.specifications: The specifications of the X-ray system include a voltage of 100 kV, a current of 15 mA, and a pixel pitch of 0.4 mm.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The performance metrics used to evaluate the YOLOv5 model include precision, recall, and F1 score.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The experimental conditions include a conveyor belt moving at a speed of 0.45 m/s, and the WPCBs being placed on the conveyor belt.
technical_parameters.materials: The materials used in this research include WPCBs, X-ray source, and dual energy line detector.
technical_parameters.processes: The processes used in this research include X-ray transmission imaging, machine learning, and value estimation.
technical_parameters.equipment: The equipment used in this research includes a Comet MXR-225HP/11 X-ray source, a Hamamatsu C10800-09FCM-C dual energy line detector, and a cluster of four workstation computers.
technical_parameters.quality_parameters: The quality parameters used to evaluate the YOLOv5 model include precision, recall, and F1 score.

paper_metadata.title: Life Cycle Assessment of Electric Vehicles – A Framework to Consider Influencing Factors
paper_metadata.citation: Patricia Egede, Tina Dettmer, Christoph Herrmann, Sami Kara, Life Cycle Assessment of Electric Vehicles – A Framework to Consider Influencing Factors, Procedia CIRP 29 (2015) 233 – 238
paper_metadata.abstract: The environmental impacts of electric vehicles (EVs) partially depend on the parameters of their site of operation. Variations of average driving patterns in different geographic locations and the use of heating and cooling due to local climate conditions have an impact on the energy consumption of EVs.

research_information.objectives: The paper proposes a framework to consider influencing factors for the ecological assessment of EVs.
research_information.methodology: The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) method is used for the quantitative ecological assessment.
research_information.key_findings: The results show that the environmental impact of EVs depends on various parameters related to the vehicle’s characteristics, their location of use and user influences.
research_information.limitations: The paper highlights the lack of transparency of the influencing factors of the LCA of EVs and the difficulty of gathering primary data.
research_information.research_questions: The paper aims to answer specific questions such as 'How long is the ecological amortisation time for lightweight materials for a specific market?'
research_information.hypotheses: The paper assumes that the environmental impact of EVs can be reduced by considering the influencing factors.
research_information.assumptions: The paper assumes that the LCA methodology is suitable for assessing the environmental impact of EVs.
research_information.scope: The paper focuses on the life cycle assessment of electric vehicles.

paper_metadata.title: Material extrusion additive manufacturing and experimental testing of topology-optimised passive heat sinks using a thermally-conductive plastic filament
paper_metadata.citation: E. Huttunen, M.T. Nykänen, J. Alexandersen, Material extrusion additive manufacturing and experimental testing of topology-optimised passive heat sinks using a thermally-conductive plastic filament, Additive Manufacturing 59 (2022) 103123
paper_metadata.abstract: This paper presents an experimental study of topology-optimised passive heat sinks produced in a thermally-conductive plastic using material extrusion additive manufacturing.

research_information.objectives: The study investigates the printing properties and performance of a thermally-conductive plastic developed for additive manufacturing using the material extrusion method called Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) method.
research_information.methodology: The study was performed through experimental tests and scanning electron microscope (SEM) imaging. Several heat sinks were printed from the material and compared to a correspondingly sized reference straight-fin heat sink in both the filament and extruded aluminium.
research_information.key_findings: Topology-optimised heat sinks achieve a 5-10% improvement in thermal resistance for the vertical installation direction and a 15-20% improvement for the horizontal direction.
research_information.limitations: The print settings may not be optimal in terms of cooling properties, and further improvement could be made based on a suitable thermal conductivity test.
research_information.research_questions: The study aims to investigate the suitability of a thermally-conductive plastic filament for heat sinks and the performance of topology-optimised heat sinks produced using additive manufacturing.
research_information.hypotheses: The study hypothesizes that topology-optimised heat sinks can achieve improved performance compared to traditional heat sink designs.
research_information.assumptions: The study assumes that the thermal conductivity of the material is isotropic and that the printing process does not affect the material properties.
research_information.scope: The study focuses on the design and testing of topology-optimised passive heat sinks using a thermally-conductive plastic filament.

measurements.thermal_conductivity: The thermal conductivity of the Ice9 Rigid Nylon material was measured to be 3.23 W/(m K) in-layer and 0.88 W/(m K) cross-layer.
measurements.temperature: The temperature of the heat source was set to 15 W.
measurements.voltage: The voltage of the heat source was measured to be 16.61 V.
measurements.current: The current of the heat source was measured to be 0.918 A.

specifications.heat_sink_dimensions: The outer dimensions of the heat sink were 76.1 mm x 76.1 mm x 57.15 mm.
specifications.fin_width: The fin width was 3 mm at the base and 2 mm at the tip.
specifications.fin_spacing: The fin spacing was 7 mm at the base.

performance_metrics.cooling_performance: The cooling performance of the heat sinks was evaluated based on the thermal resistance values.

equations.equation_1: The thermal conductivity is calculated using the one-sided guarded hot plate method with a single sample.
equations.equation_2: The governing equations for the passive heat sinks are the steady-state incompressible Navier–Stokes equations coupled to the convection–diffusion equation through the Boussinesq approximation.
equations.equation_3: The Brinkman penalisation coefficient is defined as.
equations.equation_4: The volumetric heat generation is defined as.
equations.equation_5: The thermal conductivity tensor is defined as.
equations.equation_6: The thermal conductivity tensor for the fluid is assumed to be isotropic.
equations.equation_7: The thermal conductivity tensor for the solid layer-by-layer Ice9 Rigid Nylon material is assumed to be isotropic within the layer (in-layer il) but different across the layers (cross-layer cl).
equations.equation_8: The design field is relaxed and described using a continuous design field.
equations.equation_9: The two spatially-varying material properties are coupled to the design field through interpolation functions.
equations.equation_10: The 4-step continuation approach is taken to gradually change certain parameters to avoid poor local minima and obtain well-defined design fields.
equations.equation_11: The thermal resistance is calculated based on the measured values.
equations.equation_12: The calculation of the measurement error for thermal resistance is carried out using partial derivatives.

paper_metadata.title: A LIFE CYCLE INVENTORY OF ALUMINIUM DIE CASTING
paper_metadata.citation: Roberts, M. J., Hu, E. J., & Nahavandi, S. (2003). A Life Cycle Inventory of Aluminium Die Casting. Paper submitted to APCSEET 2003
paper_metadata.abstract: This paper presents a life cycle inventory (LCI) of aluminium high pressure die casting (HPDC) and discusses the environmental consequences of the process. The study was conducted at a modern aluminium HPDC plant in Victoria, Australia, and site-specific data on energy and materials was gathered. The results show that the HPDC process is energy intensive, with major emissions from the use of natural gas fired furnaces and brown coal derived electricity. The study also highlights the environmental benefits of using secondary aluminium over primary aluminium in the HPDC process.

research_information.objectives: The objective of the study was to analyse the HPDC process and suggest changes to reduce environmental impacts.
research_information.methodology: The study was performed in accordance with the ISO 14040 series of standards for LCA. Site-specific data was gathered from the site of one aluminium die casting plant, and the process was modelled using a typical automotive component.
research_information.key_findings: The HPDC process is energy intensive, with major emissions from the use of natural gas fired furnaces and brown coal derived electricity. The use of secondary aluminium over primary aluminium in the HPDC process has large environmental benefits.
research_information.limitations: The study has limitations due to the variability of the data and the use of estimations from available databases. The results may not be repeatable and may vary from casting to casting and site to site.
research_information.research_questions: The study aims to answer the question of how much aluminium die casting contributes to global warming and what improvements can be made to lessen the environmental load created by the manufacture of the product.
research_information.hypotheses: The study hypothesizes that the use of secondary aluminium over primary aluminium in the HPDC process will have large environmental benefits.
research_information.assumptions: The study assumes that the data collected is representative of the HPDC process and that the use of estimations from available databases is acceptable.
research_information.scope: The scope of the study is to conduct a life cycle inventory of the HPDC process and to identify areas for improvement to reduce environmental impacts.

paper_metadata.title: 48 V NETWORK ADOPTION FOR AUTOMOTIVE LIGHTING SYSTEMS
paper_metadata.citation: COSTEL-CIPRIAN RAICU, GEORGE-CĂLIN SERIŢAN, BOGDAN-ADRIAN ENACHE, 48 V NETWORK ADOPTION FOR AUTOMOTIVE LIGHTING SYSTEMS, Rev. Roum. Sci. Techn.– Électrotechn. et Énerg., Vol. 66, 4, pp. 231–236, Bucarest, 2021
paper_metadata.abstract: The paper studies the trade-off between the 12 V network and the 48 V network with its benefits for automotive lighting systems, focusing on power efficiency, weight reduction, and CO2 emission reduction.

research_information.objectives: The research aims to investigate the benefits of adopting a 48 V network for automotive lighting systems, including power efficiency, weight reduction, and CO2 emission reduction.
research_information.methodology: The study uses virtual simulation tools to simulate the power architectures of a vehicle and reflect the benefits of a 48 V network for lighting systems.
research_information.key_findings: The adoption of a 48 V network can improve power efficiency, reduce total vehicle weight, and lower CO2 emissions.
research_information.limitations: The study has limitations, including the assumption of ideal values for line resistance and the neglect of transients or thermal impacts.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions include the impact of line resistance on system efficiency, the benefits of adopting a 48 V network, and the potential for weight reduction and CO2 emission reduction.
research_information.hypotheses: The hypothesis is that the adoption of a 48 V network can improve power efficiency, reduce total vehicle weight, and lower CO2 emissions.

paper_metadata.title: Thermally Conductive Plastics for Enhanced Thermal Management
paper_metadata.citation: not available
paper_metadata.abstract: Electronic devices continue to shrink while continuing to offer increasing functionality. This trend poses a significant challenge to design engineers who need to adequately address the increasing thermal management requirements of these devices on a shrinking footprint. Thermally conductive plastics have been gaining attention as an innovative new material option to address this challenge.

research_information.objectives: The paper aims to investigate the potential of thermally conductive plastics to replace aluminum as a heat sink material in thermal management applications.
research_information.methodology: The paper uses a combination of theoretical analysis and finite element analysis to explore the potential of thermally conductive plastics to replace aluminum as a heat sink material.
research_information.key_findings: The results show that thermally conductive plastics can potentially replace aluminum as a heat sink material in convection-limited environments with little or no penalty in thermal performance.
research_information.limitations: The paper notes that the simulations assume perfect interfaces and do not take into account contact resistances at interfaces, which can be significant.
research_information.research_questions: The paper explores the question of whether thermally conductive plastics can replace aluminum as a heat sink material in thermal management applications.
research_information.hypotheses: The paper hypothesizes that thermally conductive plastics can potentially replace aluminum as a heat sink material in convection-limited environments.
research_information.assumptions: The paper assumes that the thermal conductivity of the thermally conductive plastics is uniform and that the interfaces between the materials are perfect.
research_information.scope: The paper focuses on the potential of thermally conductive plastics to replace aluminum as a heat sink material in thermal management applications.

paper_metadata.title: Life-Cycle Analysis and Evaluation of Mechanical Properties of a Bio-Based Structural Adhesive
paper_metadata.citation: Tserpes, K.; Tzatzadakis, V. Life-Cycle Analysis and Evaluation of Mechanical Properties of a Bio-Based Structural Adhesive. Aerospace 2022, 9, 64.
paper_metadata.abstract: For this present paper, we performed a life-cycle analysis and an evaluation of the mechanical properties of an epichlorohydrin/cardanol adhesive in a neat and a nano-filled form.

research_information.objectives: The objectives of this study are to perform a life-cycle analysis and evaluate the mechanical properties of a novel bio-based adhesive in a neat and a nano-filled form.
research_information.methodology: The methodology used in this study includes life-cycle analysis, cost analysis, and mechanical evaluation of the bio-based adhesive.
research_information.key_findings: The key findings of this study are that the neat bio-based adhesive had a lower environmental impact and production cost compared to a commercial reference epoxy resin, while the addition of CNTs increased its environmental impact.
research_information.limitations: The limitations of this study include the lack of data in the literature for a direct comparison of the LCA findings.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions addressed in this study include the evaluation of the environmental impact and mechanical properties of the bio-based adhesive.
research_information.hypotheses: The hypotheses of this study include the expectation that the bio-based adhesive would have a lower environmental impact and production cost compared to a commercial reference epoxy resin.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions of this study include the use of data from the literature for the reference epoxy resin and the application of the life-cycle analysis methodology.
research_information.scope: The scope of this study includes the evaluation of the environmental impact and mechanical properties of the bio-based adhesive in a neat and a nano-filled form.

paper_metadata.title: Environmental Benefits of post-consumer recycled PET based Valox iQ resin vs. Valox resin using Life Cycle Assessment Approach
paper_metadata.citation: Baroth, A., Karanam, S., & McKay, R. (2011). Environmental Benefits of post-consumer recycled PET based Valox iQ resin vs. Valox resin using Life Cycle Assessment Approach. Proceedings of International Conference on Advances in Polymer Science and Rubber Technology, 3-5 March, 2011, IIT-Kharagpur
paper_metadata.abstract: Polymers play a major role in delivering and sustaining the quality, comfort and safety of modern life-styles. In addition to its impressive ratio of cost to performance, plastic products are also quickly adopting to the ‘sustainable’ or ‘green’ performance. One of the most demanded sustainable practices in polymer or plastic industry is handling of waste, which requires the polymer industry to explore new ways of using resources more efficiently.

research_information.objectives: The aim of this paper is to showcase environmental benefits of Valox iQ resin over the Valox resin using Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) methodology following ISO 14049 framework.
research_information.methodology: The LCA study was completed using SimaPro LCA software, version 7.1. The modeling was done in SimaPro version 7.1. LCA software. The study compares ‘Cradle-to-Gate’ impacts for each material.
research_information.key_findings: The results indicate that the carbon footprint as well as the total energy demand of Valox iQ resin is about 40% lesser than the traditional PBT material (Valox resin).
research_information.limitations: A sensitivity analysis based on different recycling allocation assumptions revealed that the impacts of Valox iQ resin remains lesser in almost all the situations except when the recycled PET market is constrained.
research_information.research_questions: The goal of this study was to compare the lifecycle environmental effects of Valox iQ resin compared to Valox resin.
research_information.hypotheses: The key to the reduced impact from the iQ resin is that the first life of the PET water bottles carry the burden of the fossil based raw materials.
research_information.assumptions: Allocating the full burden of the PET raw materials to the first life is the most important assumption in this study.
research_information.scope: The study compares ‘Cradle-to-Gate’ impacts for each material.

paper_metadata.title: Life Cycle Assessment of Battery Electric and Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles Considering the Impact of Electricity Generation Mix: A Case Study in China
paper_metadata.citation: Tang, B.; Xu, Y.; Wang, M. Life Cycle Assessment of Battery Electric and Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles Considering the Impact of Electricity Generation Mix: A Case Study in China. Atmosphere 2022, 13, 252.
paper_metadata.abstract: Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs) are considered to have higher energy efficiency and advantages to better control CO2 emissions compared to Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles (ICEVs). However, in the context that a large amount of thermal power is still used in developing countries, the CO2 emission reduction effectiveness of BEVs can be weakened or even counterproductive. To reveal the impact of the electricity generation mix on carbon emissions from vehicles, this paper compares the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs with ICEVs considering the regional disparity of electricity generation mix in China.

research_information.objectives: The main goal of this study is to perform a comprehensive comparison of life cycle carbon emissions between BEVs and ICEVs considering the electricity generation mix in different regions of China.
research_information.methodology: The study uses Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) to evaluate the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs and ICEVs. The LCA includes four phases: material extraction and processing, vehicle manufacturing, vehicle use, and vehicle recycling.
research_information.key_findings: The results show that the regional disparity of carbon emissions from vehicles is caused by the difference in electricity generation mix, thermal power generation technology, and electricity transmission efficiency.
research_information.limitations: The study does not consider the impact of other factors such as fuel production, transportation, and storage on the life cycle carbon emissions of vehicles.
research_information.research_questions: The study aims to answer the following research questions: (1) What is the impact of the electricity generation mix on the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs and ICEVs in China? (2) How do the regional differences in electricity generation mix affect the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs and ICEVs?
research_information.hypotheses: The study hypothesizes that the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs will be lower than those of ICEVs in regions with a high penetration of renewable energy, and higher in regions with a high penetration of thermal power.
research_information.assumptions: The study assumes that the electricity production meets the demand, and the electricity exchange among different regions is not considered.
research_information.scope: The study focuses on the life cycle carbon emissions of BEVs and ICEVs in China, considering the regional disparity of electricity generation mix.

paper_metadata.title: A Comprehensive Review on Energy Management Strategies for Electric Vehicles Considering Degradation Using Aging Models
paper_metadata.citation: Ahmad Alyakhni, Loic Boulon, Jean-Michel Vinassa, Olivier Briat. A Comprehensive Review on Energy Management Strategies for Electric Vehicles Considering Degradation Using Aging Models. IEEE Access, 2021, 9, pp.143922-143940.
paper_metadata.abstract: Electrification in the transportation industry is becoming more important to face global warming and replace fossil fuels in the future. Among the available energy sources Li-ion battery and proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) are the most promising energy sources. Therefore, employing them in fuel cell hybrid electric vehicles (FCHEVs) to combine their advantages is one of the favorable solutions. However, they still face a major challenge residing in their aging that cause the drop of system performance.

research_information.objectives: The main objective of this paper is to review the possible methods for designing a health-conscious energy management strategy (EMS) for electric vehicles, considering the degradation of Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs.
research_information.methodology: The paper reviews different degradation models for Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs, and analyzes existing works that consider the degradation of on-board energy sources in their approaches for increasing their durability.
research_information.key_findings: The paper highlights the importance of considering degradation in the design of EMSs for electric vehicles, and reviews different methods for modeling and estimating degradation, including electrochemical models, semi-empirical models, and empirical models.
research_information.limitations: The paper notes that the degradation of Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs is a complex phenomenon that is affected by many factors, and that there is no single degradation model that can accurately capture all the aging mechanisms that occur in automotive applications.
research_information.research_questions: The paper aims to answer the following research questions: What are the main degradation mechanisms of Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs? How can degradation be modeled and estimated? What are the existing methods for designing health-conscious EMSs for electric vehicles?
research_information.hypotheses: The paper hypothesizes that considering degradation in the design of EMSs for electric vehicles can improve the reliability and lifetime of the on-board energy sources.
research_information.assumptions: The paper assumes that the degradation of Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs is a critical factor that affects the performance and durability of electric vehicles.
research_information.scope: The paper focuses on the degradation of Li-ion batteries and PEMFCs in electric vehicles, and reviews different methods for modeling and estimating degradation, as well as existing works on health-conscious EMSs.

paper_metadata.title: Comparative Environmental Life Cycle Assessment of Conventional and Electric Vehicles
paper_metadata.citation: Hawkins, T. R., Singh, B., Majeau-Bettez, G., & Strømman, A. H. (2012). Comparative Environmental Life Cycle Assessment of Conventional and Electric Vehicles. Journal of Industrial Ecology, 17(1), 53-65.
paper_metadata.abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) coupled with low-carbon electricity sources offer the potential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and exposure to tailpipe emissions from personal transportation.

research_information.objectives: The primary objective of this LCA is to provide an appropriate comparison of an EV and an ICEV over their entire life cycle. A second objective is to provide a transparent inventory that can be used for assessing other vehicle and fuel options.
research_information.methodology: The study uses a process-based, attributional LCA approach, with a functional unit of 1 kilometer driven under European average conditions. The foreground LCI was compiled using secondary data sources, and Ecoinvent v2.2 was used as a background dataset.
research_information.key_findings: EVs powered by the present European electricity mix offer a 10% to 24% decrease in global warming potential (GWP) relative to conventional diesel or gasoline vehicles, assuming lifetimes of 150,000 km.
research_information.limitations: The study has several limitations, including the use of generic Ecoinvent processes, which may introduce background uncertainty, and the lack of consideration of consequential and scenario-based factors.
research_information.research_questions: The study aims to answer the question of how EVs compare to ICEVs in terms of environmental impacts, and what factors influence the environmental performance of EVs.
research_information.hypotheses: The study hypothesizes that EVs will have lower GWP impacts than ICEVs, but may have higher impacts in other categories, such as human toxicity and metal depletion.
research_information.assumptions: The study assumes a common generic vehicle glider for multiple drivetrains, and that the vehicle lifetime is 150,000 km.
research_information.scope: The study includes vehicle production, use, and end of life, as well as all relevant supply chains.

technical_parameters.measurements: The study uses several measurements, including energy consumption (in MJ/km), fuel consumption (in mL/km), and emissions (in g CO2-eq/km).
technical_parameters.specifications: The study uses a Mercedes A-Class as a reference vehicle for the ICEV, and a Nissan Leaf as a reference vehicle for the EV.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The study uses several performance metrics, including GWP, human toxicity potential (HTP), and metal depletion potential (MDP).
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The study assumes European average conditions for the use phase, and uses the New European Driving Cycle (NEDC) to estimate energy consumption.
technical_parameters.materials: The study considers several materials, including copper, nickel, and aluminum, which are used in the production of EVs.
technical_parameters.processes: The study considers several processes, including vehicle production, use, and end of life, as well as the production of electricity and fuels.
technical_parameters.equipment: The study uses several equipment, including the GREET 2.7 vehicle cycle model, and Ecoinvent v2.2 as a background dataset.
technical_parameters.quality_parameters: The study uses several quality parameters, including the ReCiPe characterization method for midpoint indicators.

paper_metadata.title: Jahresbericht über die Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022
paper_metadata.citation: BMUV und UBA: Jahresberichte über die Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022 nach Art. 7 Abs. 2 der Altfahrzeug-Richtlinie 2000/53/EG
paper_metadata.abstract: Der Bericht stellt die Ergebnisse der Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022 dar. Die Verwertungsquote für Altfahrzeuge lag bei 93,7%, während die Recyclingquote bei 86,4% lag.

research_information.objectives: Ziel des Berichts ist es, die Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022 zu ermitteln und zu bewerten.
research_information.methodology: Die Ermittlung der Verwertungsquoten erfolgte auf Basis von Daten aus der Abfallstatistik, der Außenhandelsstatistik und anderen Quellen.
research_information.key_findings: Die Verwertungsquote für Altfahrzeuge lag bei 93,7%, während die Recyclingquote bei 86,4% lag.
research_information.limitations: Die Ermittlung der Verwertungsquoten ist mit Unsicherheiten verbunden, insbesondere bei der Schätzung der Stilllegungsquote.
research_information.research_questions: Wie hoch sind die Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022?
research_information.hypotheses: Es wird angenommen, dass die Verwertungsquote für Altfahrzeuge in Deutschland im Jahr 2022 über 90% liegt.
research_information.assumptions: Es wird angenommen, dass die Daten aus der Abfallstatistik und der Außenhandelsstatistik korrekt und vollständig sind.
research_information.scope: Der Bericht bezieht sich auf die Altfahrzeug-Verwertungsquoten in Deutschland im Jahr 2022.

paper_metadata.title: Influence of Composition on the Environmental Impact of a Cast Aluminum Alloy
paper_metadata.citation: Gómez, P.; Elduque, D.; Sarasa, J.; Pina, C.; Javierre, C. Influence of Composition on the Environmental Impact of a Cast Aluminum Alloy. Materials 2016, 9, 412.
paper_metadata.abstract: The influence of alloy composition on the environmental impact of the production of six aluminum casting alloys has been analyzed. In order to perform a more precise environmental impact calculation, Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) with ReCiPe Endpoint methodology has been used, with the EcoInvent v3 AlMg3 aluminum alloy dataset as a reference.

research_information.objectives: The main objective of this work is to assess the environmental impact of several aluminum alloys and evaluate the influence that their composition has on the environment.
research_information.methodology: The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) methodology has been used, with the EcoInvent v3 AlMg3 aluminum alloy dataset as a reference. The ReCiPe Endpoint methodology has been applied to evaluate the environmental impact of each aluminum alloy.
research_information.key_findings: The overall impact of the studied balanced aluminum alloys varies from 6.09 × 10^−1 pts to 1.01 pts per kg, depending on the alloy composition. The alloying elements that contribute to increased environmental impact are copper and tin.
research_information.limitations: The study only considers the production phase of the aluminum alloys and does not take into account the use and end-of-life phases.
research_information.research_questions: What is the influence of alloy composition on the environmental impact of cast aluminum alloys? How do different alloying elements contribute to the environmental impact of aluminum alloys?
research_information.hypotheses: It is hypothesized that the composition of aluminum alloys has a significant impact on their environmental impact, and that certain alloying elements contribute more to the environmental impact than others.
research_information.assumptions: It is assumed that the EcoInvent v3 AlMg3 aluminum alloy dataset is a suitable reference for the LCA analysis, and that the ReCiPe Endpoint methodology is a suitable method for evaluating the environmental impact of aluminum alloys.
research_information.scope: The study focuses on the production phase of six aluminum casting alloys and evaluates their environmental impact using LCA.

technical_parameters.measurements: The environmental impact of each aluminum alloy is measured in points per kilogram (pts/kg), using the ReCiPe Endpoint methodology.
technical_parameters.specifications: The specifications of the aluminum alloys are given in terms of their composition, with ranges of values for each alloying element.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The performance metrics used to evaluate the environmental impact of the aluminum alloys include the ReCiPe Endpoint methodology and the Global Warming Potential (GWP) expressed in kg CO2eq.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The experimental conditions for the production of the aluminum alloys are not specified, but it is assumed that the production process is similar for all alloys.
technical_parameters.materials: The materials used in the study are six aluminum casting alloys, with different compositions and properties.
technical_parameters.processes: The processes used to produce the aluminum alloys are not specified, but it is assumed that the production process involves melting and casting of the alloys.
technical_parameters.equipment: The equipment used to produce the aluminum alloys is not specified, but it is assumed that the equipment includes furnaces, casting machines, and other machinery.

paper_metadata.title: Investigation of Thermal Management Materials for Automotive Electronic Control Units
paper_metadata.citation: Sabuj Mallik, Ndy Ekere, Chris Best, Raj Bhatti. Investigation of Thermal Management Materials for Automotive Electronic Control Units. Applied Thermal Engineering, 2010, 31 (2-3), pp.355.
paper_metadata.abstract: Today’s electronics packages are smaller and more powerful than ever before. This leads to ever increasing thermal challenges for the systems designer. The automotive electronic control unit (ECU) package faces the same challenge of thermal management as the industry in general.

research_information.objectives: The aim of this paper is to outline the results from an investigation of the thermal management materials which may be applicable to an automotive ECU.
research_information.methodology: The study is made up of three main sections. The first section reports on the use of metal matrix composites (MMCs) and thermal conductive polymers as thermal management materials for ECU housings.
research_information.key_findings: The use of metal matrix composite materials can offer significant improvements in thermal performance when compared to the traditional materials currently used in ECU’s.
research_information.limitations: The use of composite materials as thermal management materials will incur additional costs.
research_information.research_questions: The paper explores the option to find out alternative thermal management materials to aid in the ECU design.
research_information.hypotheses: The authors hypothesize that the use of metal matrix composites can offer significant improvements in thermal performance.
research_information.assumptions: The authors assume that the improvements in thermal performance will more than help to offset the additional costs.
research_information.scope: The study provides an overview of the thermal MMCs including their properties, the processing options and overall costs.

paper_metadata.title: Recent Advances and Trends in On-Board Embedded and Networked Automotive Systems
paper_metadata.citation: Lucia Lo Bello, Riccardo Mariani, Saad Mubeen, Sergio Saponara
paper_metadata.abstract: Modern cars consist of a number of complex embedded and networked systems with steadily increasing requirements in terms of processing and communication resources. Novel automotive applications, such as automated driving, rise new needs and novel design challenges that cover a broad range of hardware/software engineering aspects.

research_information.objectives: The aim of this paper is to provide an overview of the current technological challenges in on-board and networked automotive systems, reviewing the state-of-the-art design strategies and also pointing to the upcoming solutions.
research_information.methodology: The paper surveys current solutions and future trends on models and languages for automotive software development, on-board computational platforms, in-car network architectures and communication protocols, and novel design strategies for cybersecurity and functional safety.
research_information.key_findings: The paper identifies the need for new E/E architectures, exploiting eHPC and number-crunching accelerators, supervised by a safe and secure MCU, to meet the computation and memory requirements in the order of TOPS and TB, respectively, for perception and fusion tasks.
research_information.limitations: The paper does not provide a comprehensive analysis of the security vulnerabilities of current in-vehicle networking technologies.
research_information.research_questions: What are the current technological challenges in on-board and networked automotive systems? What are the upcoming solutions for these challenges?
research_information.hypotheses: The paper hypothesizes that the use of eHPC and number-crunching accelerators, supervised by a safe and secure MCU, can meet the computation and memory requirements for perception and fusion tasks in automated driving.
research_information.assumptions: The paper assumes that the automotive industry will continue to adopt more complex and sophisticated technologies, such as automated driving and V2X connectivity.
research_information.scope: The paper focuses on on-board embedded and networked automotive systems, with a special emphasis on automotive software development, on-board computational platforms, in-car network architectures, and cybersecurity.

paper_metadata.title: The ecoinvent database version 3 (part I): overview and methodology
paper_metadata.citation: Wernet, G., Bauer, C., Steubing, B., Reinhard, J., Moreno-Ruiz, E., & Weidema, B. (2016). The ecoinvent database version 3 (part I): overview and methodology. International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 21(9), 1218-1230.
paper_metadata.abstract: The ecoinvent database is the largest transparent unit-process life cycle inventory (LCI) database worldwide. Version 3 of the database was published in 2013, introducing several significant methodological and technological improvements. This article describes the methodological developments, including the separation of modeling choices and raw data, the introduction of flow properties, and the application of different system models.

research_information.objectives: The objective of the ecoinvent database is to provide a robust and flexible data system for the management of a global inventory database, supporting regionalized LCI data and regionalized life cycle impact assessment (LCIA), and allowing for the application of multiple system models.
research_information.methodology: The methodology used in the development of ecoinvent version 3 includes the separation of modeling choices and raw data, the introduction of flow properties, and the application of different system models, including allocation and cutoff by classification, allocation at the point of substitution, and consequential, long-term, small scale.
research_information.key_findings: The key findings of the study include the introduction of global background data, market datasets, and the application of different system models, which allow for more flexibility and transparency in LCI and LCIA studies.
research_information.limitations: The limitations of the study include the fact that the global datasets are often not reflecting truly global data collection, but rather extrapolated from regional data, and that the consequential model is still in its basic form and requires further development.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions addressed in the study include how to improve the methodology and data quality of the ecoinvent database, and how to support regionalized LCI and LCIA studies.
research_information.hypotheses: The hypotheses of the study include the assumption that the separation of modeling choices and raw data, and the introduction of flow properties, will improve the transparency and flexibility of the database.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions of the study include the assumption that the global datasets are representative of the global average, and that the consequential model is a suitable approach for consequential LCA studies.
research_information.scope: The scope of the study includes the development of the ecoinvent database, and the application of the database in LCI and LCIA studies.

technical_parameters.measurements: The measurements used in the study include the calculation of mass and energy balances, water balances, and carbon balances, as well as the use of flow properties such as wet and dry mass, water content, and carbon content.
technical_parameters.specifications: The specifications of the study include the use of the ecospold 2 data format, which allows for the description of exchange data independent of process data, and the inclusion of fields for exchange properties.
technical_parameters.performance_metrics: The performance metrics used in the study include the calculation of LCI and LCIA results, as well as the use of sensitivity analysis to assess the effects of modeling choices.
technical_parameters.experimental_conditions: The experimental conditions of the study include the use of a database with over 10,000 datasets, and the application of different system models to assess the effects of modeling choices.
technical_parameters.materials: The materials used in the study include the ecoinvent database, and the use of various software tools to support data management and analysis.
technical_parameters.processes: The processes used in the study include the separation of modeling choices and raw data, the introduction of flow properties, and the application of different system models.

paper_metadata.title: A scalable life cycle inventory of an automotive power electronic inverter unit —part I: design and composition
paper_metadata.citation: Nordelöf, A., Alatalo, M., & Ljunggren Söderman, M. (2019). A scalable life cycle inventory of an automotive power electronic inverter unit —part I: design and composition. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(1), 78–92.
paper_metadata.abstract: A scalable life cycle inventory (LCI) model for a power electronic inverter unit intended for controlling electric vehicle propulsion motors has been developed. The model provides mass composition and manufacturing data for an inverter unit, and it represents a typical stand-alone three-phase inverter unit with insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs).

research_information.objectives: The objective of this research is to develop a scalable life cycle inventory (LCI) model for a power electronic inverter unit intended for controlling electric vehicle propulsion motors.
research_information.methodology: The LCI model was developed by combining design data from material content declarations, textbooks, technology benchmarking literature, experts in industry, and product descriptions. The model calculates the mass of all subparts from an input of nominal power and DC system voltage.
research_information.key_findings: The results of the LCI model show that the composition of the inverter unit varies within the model range of 20–200 kW and 250–700 V. The model's mass estimations deviate up to 14% from the specified mass for ten examples of real inverter units.
research_information.limitations: The model has limitations due to the inherent variability in design, particularly for the casing and the laminated bus bar, which can cause uncertainty in the scaled model results.
research_information.research_questions: The research question addressed in this study is how to develop a scalable LCI model for a power electronic inverter unit that can be used for life cycle assessment (LCA) of electric vehicles.
research_information.hypotheses: The hypothesis of this study is that a scalable LCI model can be developed using a simplified linear scaling of the mass per material constituent with the nominal power for the majority of subparts, combined with relevant theory, engineering judgment, and design rules of thumb for two other key subparts.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions made in this study include that the power stage components are based on a standard concept for power modules, and that plastic film type condensers are the primary choice for DC link capacitance.
research_information.scope: The scope of this study is to develop a scalable LCI model for a power electronic inverter unit intended for controlling electric vehicle propulsion motors, and to validate the model using data from real-world inverter units.

paper_metadata.title: Accelerated life testing of Electronic Control Unit
paper_metadata.citation: Ravi Kotekallu et al.; International Journal of Advance Research, Ideas and Innovations in Technology, Volume 5, Issue 3, 2019
paper_metadata.abstract: An Electronic Control Unit (ECU) is an embedded system in automotive electronics that control one or more electro-mechanical systems or subsystems in a vehicle. For a sophisticated automotive will almost have 200 ECUs for multipurpose. Optimal Accelerated Life Test (ALT) Plan of Temperature Cycling (TC) and Mechanical Vibration (MV) for ECU are developed.

research_information.objectives: The objective of this research is to develop an optimal Accelerated Life Test (ALT) plan for Electronic Control Units (ECUs) using Temperature Cycling (TC) and Mechanical Vibration (MV) tests.
research_information.methodology: The methodology used in this research involves developing an ALT plan using TC and MV tests, and then comparing the results with Sherlock Simulation.
research_information.key_findings: The key findings of this research include the development of an optimal ALT plan for ECUs, and the comparison of the results with Sherlock Simulation.
research_information.limitations: The limitations of this research include the fact that the testing procedures were performed in a laboratory setting, and the results may not be representative of the complete system.
research_information.research_questions: The research questions addressed in this study include the development of an optimal ALT plan for ECUs, and the comparison of the results with Sherlock Simulation.
research_information.hypotheses: The hypotheses of this study include the assumption that the number of cycles, stresses, hours, etc., to failures on the test, is proportionate to the acceleration factor that would be observed at a normal usage rate.
research_information.assumptions: The assumptions of this study include the assumption that the failures modes and their effects are mutually exclusive.
research_information.scope: The scope of this study includes the development of an optimal ALT plan for ECUs, and the comparison of the results with Sherlock Simulation.

specifications.device_hours: Optimum allocation of device-hours for ALT plan is obtained from Minitab-18 with 65% Confidence Interval (CI)
specifications.stress_levels: Three stress levels are 110°C, 150°C and 180°C with singly failure censored at right

performance_metrics.reliability: Reliability of the ECU for a life of 20 years that is for 8 cycles per day of the vehicle will be 0.999854 with 65% confidence interval
performance_metrics.life_cycle: Life cycle of the ECU is estimated and compared with Sherlock Simulation

experimental_conditions.thermal_cycling: Thermal Cycling is conducted as per IEC60068 standard for a specified number of failures
experimental_conditions.mechanical_vibration: Mechanical Vibration test is carried out using Miner’s fatigue modal satisfying IEC60068 standard for a specified number of failures

materials.ecu: Electronic Control Unit (ECU) is a crucial component in the system for integration and control

processes.thermal_cycling_test: Thermal Cycling test is carried out for the same device-hours at the stresses mentioned
processes.mechanical_vibration_test: Mechanical Vibration test is carried out for the same device-hours at the stresses mentioned

equipment.thermal_cycling_chamber: Thermal Cycling Chamber using iTools Software
equipment.accelerometer: Accelerometer must be placed on the unit under test

quality_parameters.reliability: Reliability of the ECU is estimated and compared with Sherlock Simulation

life_cycle_phases.production: Various stages of ECU production is shown in figure 1
life_cycle_phases.use: The field data is given in table 1

environmental_indicators.reliability: Reliability of the ECU is estimated and compared with Sherlock Simulation

mitigation_measures.reliability_testing: Reliability testing is performed to identify design weaknesses and improve the reliability of the ECU

economic_indicators.reliability: Reliability of the ECU is estimated and compared with Sherlock Simulation

sustainability_metrics.reliability: Reliability of the ECU is estimated and compared with Sherlock Simulation

sustainable_practices.reliability_testing: Reliability testing is performed to identify design weaknesses and improve the reliability of the ECU

equations.equation_2: Af = (Nmin / Nmax) = (ΔTmax / ΔTmin)^b * exp((Ea / K) * (1 / Tkmax - 1 / Tkmin))

important_notes.note_1: The failures modes and their effects are assumed to be mutually exclusive
